name: Lennox Stewart
description: Lennox Stewart was a middle-distance runner who competed in the 800 metres at the 1972 München Olympics and at the 1971 Pan American Games. His greatest career accomplishment came at the Melrose Games when he defeated top American miler, Marty Liquori. Stewart attended Brevard College in North Carolina but transferred to the University of North Carolina, where he received an education degree in 1973. His son, Jesse, became a footballer on the Trinidad & Tobago national team and also a top Soca artist, known as College Boy Jesse, who won the Groovy Soca Monarch in 2020 with his hit “Happy Song”. Personal Best: 800 – 1:47.0 (1972).

name: Viktor Makarov
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Shooting Championships (1–1–2 1994 Milano gold: 50 m free pistol team, silver: 50 m free pistol; 2002 Lahti bronze: 10 m air pistol team and 50 m free pistol team)

name: Alevtina Olyunina-Smirnova
description: Alevtina Smirnova made her international début at the 1968 Olympic Games, where she was eleventh in the 10 km and 20th at 5 km. At the 1970 World Championships Olyunina-Smirnova won golds in both the 10 km and relay. At the 1972 Olympics, Olyunina-Smirnova won gold in the relay, was second at 10 km and fourth over 5 km. Domestically Olyunina-Smirnova won nine Soviet titles – two at 5 km (1968, 1972) and seven in the relay (1967, 1969-74). After her sporting career ended, Olynina-Smirnova worked as a cross-country skiing coach in Kostroma.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Winter Universiade (0–2–0 1970 Rovaniemi CCS silver: 10 km and 3×5 km relay (competed as Alevtina Olyunina)) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Nordic Ski Championships (3–1–0 1970 Vysoké Tatry CCS gold: 10 km and 3×5 km (competed as Alevtina Olyunina); 1972 Sapporo (Olympics) CCS gold: 3×5 km, silver: 10 km (competed as Alevtina Olyunina))

name: André Theuriet
description: He was also a French rugby international playing five matches for the national team as a scrum-half between 1909 and 1913.

name: Christine Phillip
description: Christine Phillip competed in the cross-country events at 5 and 10 km at the 1972 Sapporo Winter Games, representing East Germany, finishing 30th and 31st, respectively. She skied with SC Traktor Oberwiesenthal, whom she helped to win the 1969 national relay title. Phillip never won an individual national title.

name: Su Xiaohua
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Short Track Speed Skating Championships (0–1–0 1994 Guildford silver: 3000 m relay)

name: Jack Whitford
description: Jack Whitford was one of the Bevin Boys, conscripted to work down the coal mines in the 1940s. He followed his famous half-brother Arthur, the 10-times British champion, and also took up gymnastics and was coached by his brother at the Sketty Gym in Swansea. It was there that Jack met his future wife, and fellow gymnast, the Welsh champion Pat Evans. Jack won the first of three British Championships in 1947, succeeding Arthur, who had won the last Championship before World War II. Jack retained his title in 1948, and was also in the Swansea team that won the National Team Championships that year. Whitford was selected for that year’s Olympics, but did not take part after breaking an arm. His wife Pat, however, who he married in 1946, represented the family at the London Games. Whitford eventually went to the Olympics in 1952 after winning his third British title that year. Whitford and his wife Pat were married for 71 years before her death in 2020. They ran “Whitfords”, a successful family shoe shop in Swansea. Whitford, like his father before him, learned his trade as a master shoe repairer. Pat and Jack both played golf at Langland Bay Golf Club and Jack was a member of the Mumbles Lifeboat crew for many years.
special_notes: Half-brother of Arthur Whitford Husband of Pat Evans

name: Melina Hamilton
description: Personal Best: PV – 4.40 (2003).

name: Lauri Aus
description: Lauri Aus was a decent sprinter, and managed a 5th place in the 1992 Olympic road race as second of the pack behind future top sprinter Erik Zabel. He turned pro in 1995, always riding for French teams, supporting his compatriot Jaan Kirsipuu in winning several Tour de France stages. Aus himself won various races, but only in minor competition; his most important wins were the 2000 Estonian titles in both the road race and time trial. In 2003, he was killed while training, struck by a drunk driver.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Died in Motor Vehicle Accidents (Boat/Car/Motorcycle/Train) (Died when hit by a truck during training.)

name: Craig Buck
description: Craig Buck played collegiate volleyball for Pepperdine University, earning All-American honors in 1980 and 1981. A member of the U.S. Junior National Team from 1976 to 1979, Buck was named Most Valuable Player at the AAU Championships and the US Junior Nationals in 1978. He was a member of the US National Team from 1981-88, winning two gold medals at the 1984 and 1988 Olympics. At 6-9 (2.05) Buck was a redoubtable presence on the front line. He was MVP at the 1985 USA Cup and the 1987 Savin Cup. At the 1986 World Championships, won by the United States, he was named Best Server, and was named to the All-Tournament team. Buck also won a gold medal at the 1985 World Cup. After the 1988 Olympics he played professionally in France and Italy from 1988-91, and then played in Japan. He played four-man beach volleyball from 1991-97 in the Pro Four-Man Tour. Buck and his family later settled in Colorado.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Pan American Games (1–0–0 1987 Indianapolis VOL gold) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Volleyball Championships (1–0–0 1986 FRA gold)

name: Marin Popescu
description: Marin Popescu had the following podium finishes at the Flatwater World Championships: 2nd 1994 K4 200 m (with Sorin Petcu, Geza Magyar, and the non-Olympian Florin Scoica), 2nd 1994 K4 500 m (with Sorin Petcu, Geza Magyar, and the non-Olympian Florin Scoica), 3rd 1993 K1 1000 m.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Canoe Sprint World Championships (0–2–1 1993 København bronze: K1 1000 m; 1994 Ciudad de México silver: K4 200 m and K4 500 m)

name: Fred Roethlisberger
description: Fred Roethlisberger attended the University of Wisconsin, graduating in 1965, and also competed for the Milwaukee Turners. Roethlisberger starred at the 1967 Pan American Games, winning six medals and four golds, with gold in the all-around, the team event, parallel bars, and horizontal bars. He also competed at the 1966 World Championships. Roethlisberger became much better known as a coach, coaching at the University of Minnesota for 33 years. During that time he won 11 Big 10 Championships, including five consecutive from 1976-80. He was Midwest Region Coach of the Year five times. Roethlisberger coached his son, John Roethlisberger, who competed at the 1992, 1996, and 2000 Olympics, and his daughter, Marie, who was an alternate to the 1984 Olympic team. He also coached the United States to a gold medal at the 1994 World Championships and was an assistant coach on the 1992 US Olympic team. Roethlisberger was inducted into the US Gymnastics Hall of Fame in 1990.
special_notes: Father of John Roethlisberger Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Summer Pan American Games (4–1–1 1967 Winnipeg GYM gold: all-around, parallel bars, horizontal bar, and team, silver: rings, bronze: horse vault)

special_notes: Daughter of Sylvia Muehlberg Sister of Carrie Quigley Sister of Sue Banks Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the British Empire/Commonwealth Games (0–1–0 1998 Kuala Lumpur SHO silver: 10 m air rifle/pairs (competed as Lindy Muehlberg))

name: Ralph Townsend, Jr.
description: Ralph Townsend graduated from Lebanon High School in New Hampshire and then attended the University of New Hampshire (UNH), where he was in Army ROTC. He served in the 10th Mountain Division during World War II. Townsend served as a squad leader in the third platoon of K Company, 8th Regiment of 10th Mountain Division. In March 1945, K Company led the attack on the steep hill of Cimon della Piella, Italy, with Townsend suffering serious wounds, for which he received the Purple Heart, but was told by doctors that he would not be able to ski competitively again. Despite that warning, Townsend did ski again and quite well. Returning to UNH he won two US cross-country titles in 1947 and 1949. He graduated from UNH in 1949 and earned a masters degree in 1953. In 1950 Ralph Townsend began a career at Williams College as a phys ed professor, ski coach, and assistant coach for both football and lacrosse. A legend at Williams, he founded the Williams Outing Club, helped build the Berlin Mountain Ski Area, and worked in ski administration nationally as well. He was director of the US Eastern Amateur Ski Association in 1951, President of the Eastern Intercollegiate Ski Association (1958-60), and secretary of the NCAA Ski Rules Committee in 1962. In his honor, in 1959 Williams began awarding the Ralph J. Townsend Ski Trophy to the best men’s skier. Townsend was inducted into the US Ski Hall of Fame in 1975. He has also been inducted into the Army ROTC Hall of Fame.

name: Fernand Carrez
description: Fernand Carrez played hockey (field) for Belgium at the 1928 Amsterdam Olympics and then played ice hockey at the 1936 Winter Olympics. He had a long ice hockey career, from 1933-50, always centered around Bruxelles, mostly playing for Club des Sports d’Hiver Brussels, although he had stints with Brussels IHC, and Etôile du Nord. Carrez was on the Belgium ice hockey team from 1935-40 and also skated at the 1939 World Championships. He was a center in the 1930s but moved to defense after World War II.

name: Ralph Havens
description: At the time of the 1972 Winter Olympics, Ralph Havens had been competing in luge for three years and three years internationally as well. He was from San Diego, having attended Hoover High School. Havens competed at the 1970 World Championships, placing 60th in singles.

name: James Eagan
description: James Eagan was a Baltimore native who attended Johns Hopkins University. He played for Johns Hopkins when they represented the USA at the 1928 Olympic lacrosse demonstration. Eagan started at second attack in the tournament. Eagan earned a law degree from Harvard and then joined the private Baltimore firm of Armstrong, Machen and Allen. He later worked as a counsel for the US Fidelity and Guaranty Company. In 1935 he joined the legal department of the American Oil Company, and was later general solicitor and secretary of Standard Oil of Indiana. During World War II, Eagan served in the Navy as a lieutenant-commander.

name: Erich Siebert
description: Light-heavyweight wrestler Erich Siebert won the freestyle bronze medal at the 1936 Berlin Olympics. In the final round he lost by decision (3-0) to Estonian August Neo leaving the gold medal to Swede Knut Fridell as Siebert and Neo had reached the five bad points. Two years earlier he was placed second at the Greco-Roman European Championships. In 1934 and 1943 he won the German Greco-Roman Championships and also at freestyle in 1936. He was the great opponent of communist Werner Seelenbinder, and not only on the wrestling mat. As a trained policeman, he joined the SS early during the Nazi regime and hated Seelenbinder for his political thinking and also for his frequent losses to him as a wrestler. Siebert was deployed in the Jewish Ghetto of Litzmannstadt (nowadays Łódź in Poland) during World War II. He was later captured by the Russians at the end the war and died in a POW camp in 1947.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Were Killed or Missing in Action or Died as a Result of War (†1947. Died during captivity post-World War II.)

name: Lyudmila Yegorova
description: Lyudmila Yegorova was a member of the Soviet gymnastics team that won medals in the team all-around (gold) and the now-defunct portable apparatus (bronze). Individually, she fared best in the horse vault (9th), an event in which she had won two bronze medals at the Soviet Championships. In 1955 and 1956, she was also runner-up in the individual all-around at these championships. Yegorova also excelled in acrobatics, winning a national title in 1950. She later graduated from the Leningrad Physical Culture Institute, and worked as a gymnastics teacher and coach. At the time of her death she was the chairman of the Kaliningrad branch of Russian Athletes’ Union

name: Seppo Simola

name: Gaston Kouadio
description: Personal Best: 100 – 10.5 (1977).

name: Andrzej Mateja
description: Andrzej Mateja competed in cross-country skiing at the 1956 and 1960 Winter Olympics. He later worked for many years in mountain rescue services, starting his training for that in 1956 and working full-time in the mountain service from 1966-94. In his career he took part in 208 rescue expeditions and returned almost 300 injured skiiers from the slopes. In 1988 Mateja became an instructor in mountain rescues.

name: Oiva Halmetoja

name: Bohumil Prošek
description: Bohumil Prošek was a left winger who competed for Czechoslovakia at the 1956 Winter Olympics. He also represented his country at the World Championships in 1957, 1959, and 1961. Prošek started his club career in 1949 with Klano, playing with them through 1952. He later skated for Bratislava in 1952-53, before moving to RH Brno from 1953-58. Prošek skated with SONP Kladno from 1958-65, and then finished his career with Slavia Praha in 1965-67.

name: Hajar Al-Khaldi
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Asian Games (1–0–0 2018 Jakarta/Palembang ATH gold: 4×100 m relay)

name: Jenő Zsigmondy
description: Jenő von Zsigmondy played singles and doubles tennis at both the 1908 and 1912 Olympics. Von Zsigmondy was Hungarian singles champion in 1907, 1910, and 1911. He was mixed doubles champion with Katalin Cséry six times. In 1914 von Zsigmondy and Béla von Kehrling reached the semi-finals of the World Hard Court Championships in doubles. Shortly after that von Zsigmondy stopped playing tennis because of health issues, and became a top golfer. He won two titles at the 1929 Wiener Golf Club championships and in 1935 a Zsigmondy Jenő Memorial Golf Tournament was held in his honor. Von Zsigmondy studied law and became a lawyer. He came from a family of high achievement. His father was a member of the Hungarian Parliament 1927-32, while his father’s cousin, Richard Adolf Zsigmondy, won the 1926 Nobel Prize for Chemistry.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians With Nobel Prizes or Related to Nobel Prize Winners (His father's cousin, Richard Adolf Zsigmondy, won the 1926 Nobel Prize in Chemistry.)

name: Rudi Cerne
description: Rudi Cerne was among the best male figure skaters in West Germany during the 1980s. He had his best international result with a fourth place at the 1984 Sarajevo Winter Games in the men’s event. The same year he also earned his only international medal, winning silver at the Budapest Europeans. Cerne also came in fifth at the 1984 Worlds. Domestically, he finished with six podiums, two golds in 1978 and 1980, two silvers in 1981-82, and finally two bronzes in 1983-84. Cerne turned professional with Holiday on Ice and then started training as a figure skating coach, but retired after being more successful as a TV presenter, first in sports programmes such as ZDF Sportreportage and Aktuelles Sportstudio. Eventually he became a TV journalist, regularly moderating Aktenzeichen XY … ungelöst, a very prominent show presenting unsolved crimes. He also regularly presented on the German sports show Sportspersons of the Year.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the European Figure Skating Championships (0–1–0 1984 Budapest silver: singles)

name: Vincent Lecrubier
description: Vincent Lecrubier had the following podium finishes at the Flatwater World Championships: 2nd 2009 K4 1000 m (with Philippe Colin, Sébastien Jouve, and the non-Olympian Guillaume Burger).
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the Canoe Sprint World Championships (0–1–0 2009 Dartmouth silver: K4 1000 m)

name: Ramli Ahmad
description: Ramli Ahmad was Malaysia’s top sprinter in the 1970s, and set a new national record in the 200 metres in 1977 with 20.7. He still held that record when he died of a stroke at only 47, while jogging. Following his track career, Ramli had been working for Malaysia Airlines. Personal Bests: 100 – 10.3 (1975); 200 – 20.7 (1976).

name: Sam Graddy
description: Sam Graddy made his international début at the 1983 Pan American Games, where he was second in the 100 metres and was a member of the gold medal winning USA 4x100 m relay team. In 1984, Graddy won the US National Championships in the 100 metres and won the NCAA 100 m title. At the 1984 Los Angeles Olympics, Graddy was second behind Carl Lewis in the 100 and ran the first leg for the American 4x100 relay, which won the gold medal with a world record time of 37.83. After graduating from the University of Tennessee, Graddy played professional football with the Denver Broncos (1987-88) and the Los Angeles (Oakland) Raiders (1990-92). Personal Best: 100 – 10.09 (1984).

name: Anky van Grunsven
description: Anky van Grunsven is the all-time leader among equestrian Olympians with nine (9) medals, and she is the only rider to win an individual event three times in a row, doing so in the individual dressage, which she won in 2000 (on Bonfire), 2004 and 2008 (on Salinero). In addition, she placed second in that event in 1996, and has won four silver team medals (in 1992, 1996, 2000 and 2008) and one team bronze. Van Grunsven has also excelled in other competitions, winning the individual gold in the World Equestrian Games of 1994 and 2006, and winning the dressage World Cup eight times (1995, 1996, 1997, 1999, 2000, 2004, 2005, 2006 and 2008).
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Were Elected Dutch Athlete of the Year (1994) Listed in Olympians Who Competed While Pregnant (5 months pregnant when she won a gold medal in 2004.)

name: Sandra Farmand
description: Sandra Farmand was a German snowboarder who finished ninth at the 1998 Nagano Winter Olympics in giant slalom. She also retired after the first qualification round in halfpipe. At the World Championships she won three golds (1995 and 1997) and one bronze (1999) medal. In 2000, she won the snowboardcross World Cup. She also won four European Championships. Farmand also won two national titles in 2001. She was a pioneer of snowboarding in Germany, and later became the fiancé of non-Olympian biathlete Andreas Fischer. By profession, she became a team manager in process management at a German bank company.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Snowboard Championships (0–0–1 1999 Berchtesgaden bronze: parallel slalom)

name: Abdullah Jaroudi, Jr.
special_notes: Son of Abdullah Jaroudi, Sr.

name: Kjell Svensson
description: A goalie, Kjell Svensson played most of his career from 1954-69 with Södertälje SK, except for short spells with Tabergs SK (1959-60) and AIK (1960-62). With Södertälje, Svensson won his only Swedish title in 1956, but was selected to the Swedish Championship all-star teams in 1960-61 and 1963-64. Svensson was also the top goalie of Swedish national team in the 1960s, being capped 148 times and playing at two Olympic and five World Championship tournaments. Svensson won Olympic silver in 1964, was a World Champion in 1962 and won silvers at the 1963 and 1967 and bronze at the 1965 World Championships. He was also a European champion in 1962, while taking silvers at the 1963, 1964 and 1967 and bronze at the 1960, 1961 and 1965 European Championships. Because of those accomplishments, Svensson was awarded the Stora Grabbars Märke (Big Boys’ Badge) #60 in ice hockey. After finishing his sports career, Svensson worked as an ice hockey coach for awhile, coaching Södertälje SK in 1972 and 1975-78 and also coaching the Swedish national ice hockey team in 1973-74. After his coaching career, Svensson had a successful career with the Swedish truck manufacturer Scania, where he eventually rose to be Senior Vice-President of truck manufacturing. Svensson was also a member of the board of directors of the Swedish Ice Hockey Association in 1986, but resigned after six months because of his career with Scania.
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the European Ice Hockey Championships (1–3–3 1960 Squaw Valley (Olympics) bronze; 1961 Genève and Lausanne bronze; 1962 Colorado Springs and Denver gold; 1963 Stockholm silver; 1964 Innsbruck (Olympics) silver; 1965 Tampere bronze; 1967 Wien silver) Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Ice Hockey Championships (1–3–1 1962 Colorado Springs and Denver gold; 1963 Stockholm silver; 1964 Innsbruck (Olympics) silver; 1965 Tampere bronze; 1967 Wien silver)

name: Joonas Olkkonen
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Shooting Championships (0–0–1 2002 Lahti bronze: double trap)

name: Jason Rouser
description: Jason Rouser ran the heats of the 4x400 relay at the 1996 Atlanta Olympics, earning a gold medal. He also won golds in the event at the 1993 and 1997 World Indoor Championships. Rouser ran at the University of Oklahoma where he was a three-time All-American, and won the 200 and 400 twice at the Big Eight Conference Championships. He finished sixth at the 1991 NCAA Meet in the 400, and was runner-up at the 1994 USA Nationals. He later became a track coach at the University of South Florida. Personal Best: 400 – 44.77 (1996).
special_notes: Listed in Olympians Who Won a Medal at the World Athletics Indoor Championships (2–0–0 1993 Toronto gold: 4×400 m relay; 1997 Paris gold: 4×400 m relay)

name: George Redlein
description: George Redlein was a Buffalo native who was on the Buffalo German team that won the 1904 Olympic basketball tournament. Miller played in every one of the Buffalo Germans’ wins at the 1904 St. Louis Olympics. The team won 111 consecutive games between 1908-10. They were inducted into the Naismith Basketball Hall of Fame in 1961. The Buffalo Germans were disbanded in 1925 after compiling a 792-86 record. Redlein went on to play for Syracuse University from 1904-08. He was a shooting forward and started for the Orangemen for three seasons. He scored a career high of 26 points against Hamilton in his sophomore year but missed his junior season after an attack of appendicitis. He led the Orange in scoring as a senior and later played some professional basketball.
